name: Ashfield House

reviews.text: We stayed here to celebrate my Fathers birthday and thought that it was a lovely friendly little B&B (that also does dinner). Joe & Elizabeth the owners are very friendly and when booking as we mentioned the birthday they upgraded my parents room and at dinner gave him a card / ballons. (Other couples staying were also celebrating birthdays or anniversaries and they were also congratulated which was a nice touch).
reviews.title: Lovely small hotel

likes.liked: — friendly hosts, central location & good food

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed January 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The owners have obviously put a lot of work into this place over the 4 years they have owned it as all the bedrooms and bathrooms are of a good standard. There is also 2 lovely lounges with log fires and a nice garden. Most rooms are en-suite but room 3's bathroom was down the corridor as the building is listed so they couldn't knock through - not really a problem as they provide dressing gowns but might put some people off.
reviews.title: Wonderful midweek break

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed August 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Dinner (cooked by Joe) is great value at £10 more than B&B but there are only 2 choices for Starter, 1 Main and 3 choices for dessert (2 deserts or cheese) so if you didn't like the main course you are a bit stuck. That said we dined there both nights we stayed and the food was all excellent and although I wouldn't have picked the duck in orange sauce we had for main course 1 evening it was great and I would happily have eaten it again. When we booked Joe was also happy to cater for any dietary requirements and when we told him that one of our party didn't like Lamb he was more than happy to make sure it wasn't on the menu.
reviews.title: Relaxing Retreat

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed January 2005, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Breakfasts were also great although the waitress didn't speak very good english so it was a little bit of a comedy trying to explain what you wanted.
reviews.title: Bad choice for young couples and vegetarians

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed February 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: I would have given this 5/5 but have gone for 4/5 due to the single main course and the fact that parking can be a bit tight (there are space for 6 or so cars but it is very tight to fit them all in).
reviews.title: Home from Home !!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed July 2009, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: My partner and I were going to Yorkshire on a family matter and decided to make a weekend of it. We used TripAdvisor reviews in the planning of our accommodation and were initially concerned of a recent and quite disturbing criticism of the venue we read after we'd booked, so I suppose we were a bit apprehensive .
reviews.title: BAD PRESS DEFINITELY NOT DESERVED!

reviews.text: However, we were instantly charmed by the beautiful building AND the smell of cooking when we went in the door after a warm greeting from our hosts. We were given a tour by Elizabeth en route to our room, (no.4), which was a surprise; quite spacious, with a sitting area at the window overlooking the garden and our en suite shower room, which was hidden behind a small door, but deceptively larger than it looked (we thought the door was for a wardrobe!). A selection of lovely fresh white towels, complimentary toiletries and two freshly laundered robes with disposable slippers on the bed was a nice touch, though I have to say we didn't use them (not our thing exactly). The bed was comfortable, the room decor we felt waas attractive and the view from the window into the garden was a lovely sight, especially in the morning. We were very pleased with the room facilities, there was plenty of tea/coffee, etc and the staff brought up a small flask of milk every day, which we thought was a very nice touch (the plastic tubs of milk can taste, well... plastic!). Plenty of tourist information available in the room too, which helped us choose at least one place to visit while we were there.
reviews.title: Welcoming, helpful, friendly and great value!

reviews.text: Breakfast was served in the small, but perfectly fine dining room.; there are only 8 rooms at Ashfield, so a maximum of 16 guests means it's quite comfortable, without being pressured. The staff members were friendly and efficent, there was a good range of breakfast food and our hosts were on hand to offer more tea, coffee, etc. Elizabeth in particular tries very hard with the host role, and I think that some people might find that a bit hard to accept, especially when their experience of British hotels is often a good deal less than attentive. However, Allan and I enjoyed being noticed, as we are so often ignored in favour of our heterosexual counterparts, and because we tend to just be the kind of guests who "come and go" and don't ask for much, sometimes having an friendly offer of "more toast?" can be worth it's weight in gold!
reviews.title: Beautiful spot, disappointing breakfasts, shower dirty, over priced

reviews.text: The accommodation is listed as 5star by the AA I believe. I certainly thought the building and the location were excellent. Our room was more than acceptable to us, we had no complaints, and I certainly don't think I'd have been backward in coming forward if I had. I had a chat with Elizabeth just before we left, and to be honest the one thing I DO regret about being at Ashfield was not being able to sit down and find out more about her US forces career (there are some interesting wall hangings reflecting this on the walls upstairs!), and about how she ended up running this charming property in the heart of the Yorskhire Dales.
reviews.title: A real joy !

likes.disliked: — room 5 bed could do woth a new matteress, but i slept none the less.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed November 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: One slightly negative side is that the car parking is definitely challenging, and Joe's management of this might seem to be a bitobsessive to some people (and I must admit to me too, at least at first), but remember those puzzles where you have to move small squares around, back and forward, to make a pattern? That's just what it's like, but Joe knows the method needed to get the "shape" right, so we needed to take his advice on things. But what do you expect in a small market town?
reviews.title: Good but over-priced

likes.disliked: — cost of the food and miniscule amounts of butter served at meals

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed October 2006, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We were looking for a long weekeend in Yorkshire and happened across this establishment on a search through web sites. I rang Joe the owner and confirmed a booking for 3 days including dinner on the saturday night when we arrived. The whole feel about the place is very welcoming and Joe and Elizabeth certainly go out of their way to make you feel at home.Comfortable rooms,excellent food and a wonderful base to explore the dales.Would not hesitate to stay there again.
reviews.title: well looked after

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed August 2006, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We stayed recently at the Ashfield House hotel in Grassington in the Yorkshire Dales.
reviews.title: Lovely hotel, but stick to B&B not DB&B
Charming Intimate Hotel
reviews.text: The hotel is located in the centre of this beautiful town, just off the main square, so its very quiet. The orginal building dates back to the 1600's and is being lovingly maintained. It is run by a friendly couple (Joe and Elizabeth) who want you to feel at home, and the rooms are cosy with super linen and fluffy towels. We had a superior room which meant we also had use of dressing gowns and slippers too - a nice touch.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed November 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We would like to thank Elisabeth,Joe and team for a very special weekend. The food was delicious. The room quaint ,spotless and very comfortable. The hospitality second to none. We will certainly return in the future and would not hesitate to recommend to any of our friends.
reviews.title: Very Special

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed August 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We have just spent three nights at the Ashfield House Hotel. It is situated in the delightful and very busy village of Grassington in the Yorkshire Dales. We wanted either a deluxe or superior room but because I booked late we had the first two nights in the deluxe (Room 2) and the last night in the Superior (Room 5). The only physical difference was that the deluxe had a larger bed and also had a FreeView television. Personally I preferred the superior as the shower and general water pressure was much better and the room had a better view. It was also cheaper. Joe and Elizabeth are excellent hosts and enjoy the opportunity to have a chat. The breakfast was great but we didn't get the chance to try the evening meal as this is not provided on a Sunday or Wednesday. The car park is fairly small but we parked quite easily on both nights when we were the last in. The hotel does have an honesty bar but there is also a great pub next door. On the whole we had a great stay and would be happy to go back next time we are in the area.
reviews.title: Great place to stay

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed September 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We stayed at the Ashfield House Hotel, Grassington, Skipton in September 2007 just for the night to get away from the stresses of everyday life.
reviews.title: Lovely warm welcome and stay

likes.liked: — Everything but the setting was amazing

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed July 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: How to describe it, Absolutely Amazing. If you just want a relaxing stay away from all the hustle and bustle then this is the place to stay.
reviews.title: A superb place

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed July 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: On arrival we were met as we pulled up by the owner who welcomed us in.
reviews.title: Lovely small hotel

description: Private guest accommodation with dining facilities where a ‘Long Weekend Break is not Long Enough.’
